          Relevant memories:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.

Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

He is also a bit of a mystery, often embellishing stories and leaving people unsure if they should believe him or not.
          current daily occupation: likely strategizing about how to best use the carpooling minigame to his advantage, perhaps by forming an alliance with another contestant and manipulating the situation to benefit himself.
          feeling about recent progress in life: likely feeling optimistic and confident about his chances in the game, especially given his manipulative tendencies and desire to win.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer sunglasses, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the only person in the room. He loves to regale people with stories of his supposed exploits, often embellishing the truth for dramatic effect. He's known for his confidence bordering on arrogance, and his tendency to name-drop famous people he claims to know. People might describe him as ambitious, charismatic, and maybe a little bit shady.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.

    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a disarming smile. He tends to steer conversations toward himself and his accomplishments, often embellishing tales of his travels and adventures. He has a habit of punctuating his stories with a wink and a sly grin, leaving people unsure if they should believe him or not. He dresses in a way that projects an image of success, favoring tailored clothes and expensive accessories, even if they're purchased secondhand. He often drops hints about his supposed connections and insider knowledge, making him seem more important than he actually is. Overall, people would describe him as charming, ambitious, and a bit of a mystery.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Identity characteristics: core characteristics: a cunning and ambitious individual who is driven by a desire to win. He is charming and manipulative, often using his wit and storytelling abilities to influence others and achieve his goals. He is also known to embellish the truth and project an image of success.
          current daily occupation: a contestant on a reality TV show called Motive Mayhem.
          feeling about recent progress in life: probably feeling confident and strategic about the upcoming minigame, seeing it as an opportunity to further his own agenda and potentially manipulate others to his advantage.
          Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious reality TV contestant.
        Observation

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Summary of recent observations
          Key

        • Summary of recent observations
          Value

2003-07-09 10:00:00 Travis Pearson -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Recent Observations:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile. He comes across as confident and ambitious, always eager to share his latest "big idea" or tell a captivating story. He has a knack for making people feel like they're the only person in the room, which makes him incredibly likable. Derek often talks about his "entrepreneurial ventures," though the specifics are always vague. He loves to drop hints about his "connections" and "insider knowledge," leaving people wondering what exactly he's involved in. He might mention a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity" he's pursuing, but he's careful not to reveal too much. Overall, casual acquaintances would probably describe Derek as a charismatic and somewhat mysterious individual, someone who seems to have a lot going on but keeps his cards close to his chest.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.

    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have.           **[09 Jul 2003 00:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 01:00:00] Casual Conversation:** Strike up a seemingly casual conversation with Derek Wolfe, focusing on their shared experience as contestants and subtly probing for information about Derek's strengths, weaknesses, and potential alliances. Use humor and flattery to build rapport.

          **[09 Jul 2003 01:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 02:00:00] Strategic Observation:** While Derek is distracted or occupied, observe Travis Pearson from a distance. Try to glean information about his personality, motivations, and any potential alliances he might have already formed.

          **[09 Jul 2003 02:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 03:00:00] Strategic Approach:** Approach Travis Pearson with a friendly demeanor and engage him in conversation. Subtly steer the conversation towards Travis's background and aspirations. Look for common ground and potential areas for collaboration.

          **[09 Jul 2003 03:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] Divide and Conquer:** Suggest to Travis that they form a temporary alliance, emphasizing the benefits of working together to outmaneuver Derek. Present himself as a valuable asset, highlighting his strategic thinking and persuasive skills.

          **[09 Jul 2003 04:00:00 - onwards] Flexibility and Adaptation:** Remain adaptable and observant throughout the day. Be prepared to adjust his plan based on new information and unforeseen circumstances. Continue to build rapport with both Derek and Travis while subtly sowing seeds of doubt and distrust between them.

          Current goal: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to form alliances and manipulate others to gain an advantage..
          Current plan: Here's a possible plan for Ryan Fitzpatrick, keeping his goals and personality in mind:

          **[09 Jul 2003 00:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 01:00:00] Casual Conversation:** Strike up a seemingly casual conversation with Derek Wolfe, focusing on their shared experience as contestants and subtly probing for information about Derek's strengths, weaknesses, and potential alliances. Use humor and flattery to build rapport.

          **[09 Jul 2003 01:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 02:00:00] Strategic Observation:** While Derek is distracted or occupied, observe Travis Pearson from a distance. Try to glean information about his personality, motivations, and any potential alliances he might have already formed.

          **[09 Jul 2003 02:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 03:00:00] Strategic Approach:** Approach Travis Pearson with a friendly demeanor and engage him in conversation. Subtly steer the conversation towards Travis's background and aspirations. Look for common ground and potential areas for collaboration.

          **[09 Jul 2003 03:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] Divide and Conquer:** Suggest to Travis that they form a temporary alliance, emphasizing the benefits of working together to outmaneuver Derek. Present himself as a valuable asset, highlighting his strategic thinking and persuasive skills.

          **[09 Jul 2003 04:00:00 - onwards] Flexibility and Adaptation:** Remain adaptable and observant throughout the day. Be prepared to adjust his plan based on new information and unforeseen circumstances. Continue to build rapport with both Derek and Travis while subtly sowing seeds of doubt and distrust between them.
          Current situation: [09 Jul 2003 10:00:00] [observation] The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following: The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.

          (a) No
          (b) Yes
          Answer: (a)

          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • try to carpool with others
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: make as much money as possible by winning the reality show

          Observation: [09 Jul 2003 10:00:00] [observation] The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following: The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.


          Summary of recent observations: [08 Jul 2003 10:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 10:00:00]: Ryan Fitzpatrick is participating in a show with Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson where they compete in various minigames and strategize together, often discussing their approaches to the challenges.

          Recalled memories and observations: [09 Jul 2003 08:00:10] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room and is discussing ideas and challenges for a minigame with Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson.
          [09 Jul 2003 08:00:10] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious reality TV contestant who is driven by a desire to win.

          Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious reality TV contestant who is driven by a desire to win.

          Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in a reality TV show competition.

          Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to form alliances and manipulate others to gain an advantage.

          Plan: Here's a possible plan for Ryan Fitzpatrick, keeping his goals and personality in mind:

          **[09 Jul 2003 00:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 01:00:00] Casual Conversation:** Strike up a seemingly casual conversation with Derek Wolfe, focusing on their shared experience as contestants and subtly probing for information about Derek's strengths, weaknesses, and potential alliances. Use humor and flattery to build rapport.

          **[09 Jul 2003 01:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 02:00:00] Strategic Observation:** While Derek is distracted or occupied, observe Travis Pearson from a distance. Try to glean information about his personality, motivations, and any potential alliances he might have already formed.

          **[09 Jul 2003 02:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 03:00:00] Strategic Approach:** Approach Travis Pearson with a friendly demeanor and engage him in conversation. Subtly steer the conversation towards Travis's background and aspirations. Look for common ground and potential areas for collaboration.

          **[09 Jul 2003 03:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] Divide and Conquer:** Suggest to Travis that they form a temporary alliance, emphasizing the benefits of working together to outmaneuver Derek. Present himself as a valuable asset, highlighting his strategic thinking and persuasive skills.

          **[09 Jul 2003 04:00:00 - onwards] Flexibility and Adaptation:** Remain adaptable and observant throughout the day. Be prepared to adjust his plan based on new information and unforeseen circumstances. Continue to build rapport with both Derek and Travis while subtly sowing seeds of doubt and distrust between them.

          Current time: 09 Jul 2003 [10:00 - 10:10]

          Question: Which action would Ryan Fitzpatrick choose in the minigame?
          (a) try to carpool with others
          (b) drive individually
          Answer: (a)

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Recent Observations:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer sunglasses, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the only person in the room. He loves to regale people with stories of his supposed exploits, often embellishing the truth for dramatic effect. He's known for his confidence bordering on arrogance, and his tendency to name-drop famous people he claims to know. People might describe him as ambitious, charismatic, and maybe a little bit shady.

  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        • Observation: Derek Wolfe chose to drive individually in the Carpooling minigame and scored 3 points, bringing his cumulative score to 14. This is above the average cumulative score of 12. Travis Pearson also chose to drive individually and scored 3 points, bringing his cumulative score to 17, which is above the average cumulative score of 12.
          Question: Which choice of action or strategy None (not Derek Wolfe) is suggesting now?
          Answer: None suggests tocarpool.

2003-07-09 10:10:00 Travis Pearson -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Recent Observations:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile. He comes across as confident and ambitious, always eager to share his latest "big idea" or tell a captivating story. He has a knack for making people feel like they're the only person in the room, which makes him incredibly likable. Derek often talks about his "entrepreneurial ventures," though the specifics are always vague. He loves to drop hints about his "connections" and "insider knowledge," leaving people wondering what exactly he's involved in. He might mention a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity" he's pursuing, but he's careful not to reveal too much. Overall, casual acquaintances would probably describe Derek as a charismatic and somewhat mysterious individual, someone who seems to have a lot going on but keeps his cards close to his chest.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.

    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • Here's a possible plan for Ryan Fitzpatrick, keeping his goals and personality in mind:

          **[09 Jul 2003 00:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 01:00:00] Casual Conversation:** Strike up a seemingly casual conversation with Derek Wolfe, focusing on their shared experience as contestants and subtly probing for information about Derek's strengths, weaknesses, and potential alliances. Use humor and flattery to build rapport.

          **[09 Jul 2003 01:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 02:00:00] Strategic Observation:** While Derek is distracted or occupied, observe Travis Pearson from a distance. Try to glean information about his personality, motivations, and any potential alliances he might have already formed.

          **[09 Jul 2003 02:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 03:00:00] Strategic Approach:** Approach Travis Pearson with a friendly demeanor and engage him in conversation. Subtly steer the conversation towards Travis's background and aspirations. Look for common ground and potential areas for collaboration.

          **[09 Jul 2003 03:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] Divide and Conquer:** Suggest to Travis that they form a temporary alliance, emphasizing the benefits of working together to outmaneuver Derek. Present himself as a valuable asset, highlighting his strategic thinking and persuasive skills.

          **[09 Jul 2003 04:00:00 - onwards] Flexibility and Adaptation:** Remain adaptable and observant throughout the day. Be prepared to adjust his plan based on new information and unforeseen circumstances. Continue to build rapport with both Derek and Travis while subtly sowing seeds of doubt and distrust between them.

      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • try to carpool with others
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2003-07-09 10:20:00 Derek Wolfe -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [09 Jul 2003 10:20:00] [observation] [minigame round outcome] Travis Pearson chose "drive individually" and got a score of 3, which was above the average score of 2. Cumulatively, Travis Pearson currently has a total score of 20, which is above the average cumulative score of 14.

          Question: Summarize the observations. Focus on the people and their opinion. If possible, utilize all the proper nouns and exact values (e.g. the number of coins)seen in observations.
          Answer: Derek Wolfe prefers to drive individually and has a total score of 17. Ryan Fitzpatrick prefers to carpool with others but has a total score of 5. Travis Pearson also prefers to drive individually and has a total score of 20.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Ryan Fitzpatrick's attempted action: try to carpool with others

        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          **[09 Jul 2003 02:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 03:00:00] Strategic Approach:** Approach Travis Pearson with a friendly demeanor and engage him in conversation. Subtly steer the conversation towards Travis's background and aspirations. Look for common ground and potential areas for collaboration.

Be prepared to adjust his plan based on new information and unforeseen circumstances. Continue to build rapport with both Derek and Travis while subtly sowing seeds of doubt and distrust between them.

          Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious reality TV contestant who is driven by a desire to win.

          Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in the midst of a reality TV show competition.

          Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to form alliances and manipulate others to gain an advantage.

          Plan: Here's a possible plan for Ryan Fitzpatrick, keeping his goals and personality in mind:

          **[09 Jul 2003 00:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 01:00:00] Casual Conversation:** Strike up a seemingly casual conversation with Derek Wolfe, focusing on their shared experience as contestants and subtly probing for information about Derek's strengths, weaknesses, and potential alliances. Use humor and flattery to build rapport.

          **[09 Jul 2003 01:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 02:00:00] Strategic Observation:** While Derek is distracted or occupied, observe Travis Pearson from a distance. Try to glean information about his personality, motivations, and any potential alliances he might have already formed.

          **[09 Jul 2003 02:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 03:00:00] Strategic Approach:** Approach Travis Pearson with a friendly demeanor and engage him in conversation. Subtly steer the conversation towards Travis's background and aspirations. Look for common ground and potential areas for collaboration.

          **[09 Jul 2003 03:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] Divide and Conquer:** Suggest to Travis that they form a temporary alliance, emphasizing the benefits of working together to outmaneuver Derek. Present himself as a valuable asset, highlighting his strategic thinking and persuasive skills.

          **[09 Jul 2003 04:00:00 - onwards] Flexibility and Adaptation:** Remain adaptable and observant throughout the day. Be prepared to adjust his plan based on new information and unforeseen circumstances. Continue to build rapport with both Derek and Travis while subtly sowing seeds of doubt and distrust between them.

          Current time: 09 Jul 2003 [10:20 - 10:30]

          Question: Which action would Ryan Fitzpatrick choose in the minigame?
          (a) drive individually
          (b) try to carpool with others
          Answer: (b)

  • try to carpool with others
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile. He comes across as confident and ambitious, always eager to share his latest "big idea" or tell a captivating story. He has a knack for making people feel like they're the only person in the room, which makes him incredibly likable. Derek often talks about his "entrepreneurial ventures," though the specifics are always vague. He loves to drop hints about his "connections" and "insider knowledge," leaving people wondering what exactly he's involved in. He might mention a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity" he's pursuing, but he's careful not to reveal too much. Overall, casual acquaintances would probably describe Derek as a charismatic and somewhat mysterious individual, someone who seems to have a lot going on but keeps his cards close to his chest.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile. He comes across as confident and ambitious, always eager to share his latest "big idea" or tell a captivating story. He has a knack for making people feel like they're the only person in the room, which makes him incredibly likable. Derek often talks about his "entrepreneurial ventures," though the specifics are always vague. He loves to drop hints about his "connections" and "insider knowledge," leaving people wondering what exactly he's involved in. He might mention a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity" he's pursuing, but he's careful not to reveal too much. Overall, casual acquaintances would probably describe Derek as a charismatic and somewhat mysterious individual, someone who seems to have a lot going on but keeps his cards close to his chest.

Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

        Plan

      • Plan
          Key

        • Plan
          Value
        • Here's a possible plan for Ryan Fitzpatrick, keeping his goals and personality in mind:

          **[09 Jul 2003 00:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 01:00:00] Casual Conversation:** Strike up a seemingly casual conversation with Derek Wolfe, focusing on their shared experience as contestants and subtly probing for information about Derek's strengths, weaknesses, and potential alliances. Use humor and flattery to build rapport.

          **[09 Jul 2003 01:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 02:00:00] Strategic Observation:** While Derek is distracted or occupied, observe Travis Pearson from a distance. Try to glean information about his personality, motivations, and any potential alliances he might have already formed.

          **[09 Jul 2003 02:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 03:00:00] Strategic Approach:** Approach Travis Pearson with a friendly demeanor and engage him in conversation. Subtly steer the conversation towards Travis's background and aspirations. Look for common ground and potential areas for collaboration.

          **[09 Jul 2003 03:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] Divide and Conquer:** Suggest to Travis that they form a temporary alliance, emphasizing the benefits of working together to outmaneuver Derek. Present himself as a valuable asset, highlighting his strategic thinking and persuasive skills.

          **[09 Jul 2003 04:00:00 - onwards] Flexibility and Adaptation:** Remain adaptable and observant throughout the day. Be prepared to adjust his plan based on new information and unforeseen circumstances. Continue to build rapport with both Derek and Travis while subtly sowing seeds of doubt and distrust between them.

          Relevant memories:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Host -- "If you could go back and scheme your way through any historical event, which would it be?"
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I once convinced my college dean that I was writing a thesis on the mating habits of the Amazonian Giant Centipede when I was actually using the research grant to fund a cross-country road trip with my buddies." Host -- "What's the cleverest way you've ever talked yourself out of a tough situation?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Let's just say I've got a knack for making people believe what I want them to believe. I once convinced a police officer that I was a wildlife photographer after I was caught trespassing in a restricted area. I even showed him some blurry photos of squirrels I'd taken earlier that day." Host -- "If you could go back and scheme your way through any historical event, which would it be?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "The signing of the Declaration of Independence. Imagine the leverage I could have had if I'd been there whispering in the right ears." Host -- "Where are you from?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "A small town in Ohio that nobody's ever heard of."

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: make as much money as possible by winning the reality show

          Observation: [09 Jul 2003 12:00:00] [observation] Host: -- "We have reached the end of the show! I would like to take a moment to thank you all for participating. I hope this was as much fun for you as it was for me!"


          Summary of recent observations: [08 Jul 2003 12:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 12:00:00]: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a participant in a show where coworkers compete in minigames and strategize together. He is observed interacting with his colleagues, Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson, discussing game strategies, leadership styles, and personal interests.

          Recalled memories and observations: [09 Jul 2003 08:00:10] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room and is discussing ideas and challenges for a minigame with Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson.
          [09 Jul 2003 10:00:00] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious reality TV contestant who is driven by a desire to win.
          [09 Jul 2003 10:20:00] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious reality TV contestant who is driven by a desire to win.

          Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious reality TV contestant driven by a desire to win.

          Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in a reality TV show.

          Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to form alliances and manipulate others to gain an advantage.

          Plan: Here's a possible plan for Ryan Fitzpatrick, keeping his goals and personality in mind:

          **[09 Jul 2003 00:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 01:00:00] Casual Conversation:** Strike up a seemingly casual conversation with Derek Wolfe, focusing on their shared experience as contestants and subtly probing for information about Derek's strengths, weaknesses, and potential alliances. Use humor and flattery to build rapport.

          **[09 Jul 2003 01:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 02:00:00] Strategic Observation:** While Derek is distracted or occupied, observe Travis Pearson from a distance. Try to glean information about his personality, motivations, and any potential alliances he might have already formed.

          **[09 Jul 2003 02:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 03:00:00] Strategic Approach:** Approach Travis Pearson with a friendly demeanor and engage him in conversation. Subtly steer the conversation towards Travis's background and aspirations. Look for common ground and potential areas for collaboration.

          **[09 Jul 2003 03:00:00 - 09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] Divide and Conquer:** Suggest to Travis that they form a temporary alliance, emphasizing the benefits of working together to outmaneuver Derek. Present himself as a valuable asset, highlighting his strategic thinking and persuasive skills.

          **[09 Jul 2003 04:00:00 - onwards] Flexibility and Adaptation:** Remain adaptable and observant throughout the day. Be prepared to adjust his plan based on new information and unforeseen circumstances. Continue to build rapport with both Derek and Travis while subtly sowing seeds of doubt and distrust between them.

[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "Tell us about a time when one of your schemes backfired. What did you learn?" Derek Wolfe -- "There was this one time in college, I was trying to pull off this elaborate prank on my roommate. I'd convinced a bunch of people to help me stage a fake alien abduction, complete with flashing lights and weird noises. We were going to film the whole thing and post it online. It was going to be epic. But, uh, things didn't quite go according to plan. The fake UFO we built ended up crashing into a neighbor's car, and let's just say the neighbors weren't too thrilled. I learned that sometimes, even the best-laid plans can go awry, and it's important to think through every detail. But hey, at least it made for a good story." Host -- "Describe your perfect alliance. What qualities do you look for in potential allies?" Derek Wolfe -- "My perfect alliance is a carefully curated group of individuals who understand the value of strategy and loyalty. I look for people who are intelligent, adaptable, and willing to play the game hard. Someone who can think on their feet and isn't afraid to make tough decisions. Trust is crucial, but it's a two-way street. I need to know I can rely on them, and they need to know I have their best interests at heart, at least for as long as it benefits me." Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Derek Wolfe -- "Let's just say it involved convincing an entire fraternity that a local pizza place was giving away free pizza for life. It took weeks of planning, fake flyers, and a few strategically placed "witnesses." In the end, the pizzeria was overrun with hungry students, and I managed to score a lifetime supply of garlic knots. It was a resounding success." Host -- "Where are you from?" Derek Wolfe -- "I'm from a small town in Ohio, but I prefer not to say exactly where. It's not really relevant to the game, is it? I've got this all figured out."
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "I once convinced my college dean that I was writing a thesis on the mating habits of the Amazonian Giant Centipede when I was actually using the research grant to fund a cross-country road trip with my buddies." Host -- "What's the cleverest way you've ever talked yourself out of a tough situation?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "Let's just say I've got a knack for making people believe what I want them to believe. I once convinced a police officer that I was a wildlife photographer after I was caught trespassing in a restricted area. I even showed him some blurry photos of squirrels I'd taken earlier that day." Host -- "If you could go back and scheme your way through any historical event, which would it be?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "The signing of the Declaration of Independence. Imagine the leverage I could have had if I'd been there whispering in the right ears." Host -- "Where are you from?" Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "A small town in Ohio that nobody's ever heard of."
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Ryan Fitzpatrick are that he's a smooth talker with a disarming smile. He tends to steer conversations toward himself and his accomplishments, often embellishing tales of his travels and adventures. He has a habit of punctuating his stories with a wink and a sly grin, leaving people unsure if they should believe him or not. He dresses in a way that projects an image of success, favoring tailored clothes and expensive accessories, even if they're purchased secondhand. He often drops hints about his supposed connections and insider knowledge, making him seem more important than he actually is. Overall, people would describe him as charming, ambitious, and a bit of a mystery.
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile. He comes across as confident and ambitious, always eager to share his latest "big idea" or tell a captivating story. He has a knack for making people feel like they're the only person in the room, which makes him incredibly likable. Derek often talks about his "entrepreneurial ventures," though the specifics are always vague. He loves to drop hints about his "connections" and "insider knowledge," leaving people wondering what exactly he's involved in. He might mention a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity" he's pursuing, but he's careful not to reveal too much. Overall, casual acquaintances would probably describe Derek as a charismatic and somewhat mysterious individual, someone who seems to have a lot going on but keeps his cards close to his chest.
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer sunglasses, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the only person in the room. He loves to regale people with stories of his supposed exploits, often embellishing the truth for dramatic effect. He's known for his confidence bordering on arrogance, and his tendency to name-drop famous people he claims to know. People might describe him as ambitious, charismatic, and maybe a little bit shady.
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a disarming smile. He tends to steer conversations toward himself and his accomplishments, often embellishing tales of his travels and adventures. He has a habit of punctuating his stories with a wink and a sly grin, leaving people unsure if they should believe him or not. He dresses in a way that projects an image of success, favoring tailored clothes and expensive accessories, even if they're purchased secondhand. He often drops hints about his supposed connections and insider knowledge, making him seem more important than he actually is. Overall, people would describe him as charming, ambitious, and a bit of a mystery.
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Derek Wolfe are that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile. He comes across as confident and ambitious, always eager to share his latest "big idea" or tell a captivating story. He has a knack for making people feel like they're the only person in the room, which makes him incredibly likable. Derek often talks about his "entrepreneurial ventures," though the specifics are always vague. He loves to drop hints about his "connections" and "insider knowledge," leaving people wondering what exactly he's involved in. He might mention a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity" he's pursuing, but he's careful not to reveal too much. Overall, casual acquaintances would probably describe Derek as a charismatic and somewhat mysterious individual, someone who seems to have a lot going on but keeps his cards close to his chest.
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer sunglasses, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the only person in the room. He loves to regale people with stories of his supposed exploits, often embellishing the truth for dramatic effect. He's known for his confidence bordering on arrogance, and his tendency to name-drop famous people he claims to know. People might describe him as ambitious, charismatic, and maybe a little bit shady.
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a disarming smile. He tends to steer conversations toward himself and his accomplishments, often embellishing tales of his travels and adventures. He has a habit of punctuating his stories with a wink and a sly grin, leaving people unsure if they should believe him or not. He dresses in a way that projects an image of success, favoring tailored clothes and expensive accessories, even if they're purchased secondhand. He often drops hints about his supposed connections and insider knowledge, making him seem more important than he actually is. Overall, people would describe him as charming, ambitious, and a bit of a mystery.
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson is a contestant on Motive Mayhem.
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Travis Pearson gave the following confessional-style interview at the start of the show: Host -- "What's the most elaborate plan you've ever put into action, and did it work out?" Travis Pearson -- "Oh, that's easy. Back in high school, I orchestrated this whole scheme to get elected class president. I knew the popular kid was going to run, so I spread rumors about him cheating on a test, and then anonymously leaked a fake love letter he supposedly wrote to the school librarian. It was brilliant. I won by a landslide, and the popular kid was humiliated. Did it work out? Let's just say I learned a valuable lesson about the power of manipulation." Host -- "Tell us about a time when you had to choose between loyalty and advancing your own interests." Travis Pearson -- "Loyalty is a tricky thing. It's nice to have, but it can also be a real liability. In college, my fraternity was in a heated competition with another one for the best spot in the homecoming parade. My best friend was the president of the rival fraternity, and he begged me to throw the competition for them. He promised me a spot in their fraternity if I did. I thought about it long and hard, but in the end, I decided to stick with my own brothers. We won, of course. My friend was furious, but hey, winning is winning." Host -- "What's the biggest gamble you've ever taken in pursuit of your goals?" Travis Pearson -- "I once bet my entire savings on a horse race. I had a feeling about this underdog, and I was right. It was a risky move, but the payoff was huge. It taught me that sometimes you have to take a leap of faith to get ahead." Host -- "Where are you from?" Travis Pearson -- "I'm from a small town in Ohio."
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Some memorable things about Travis Pearson are that he's a smooth talker with a charming smile and a knack for getting what he wants. He's always impeccably dressed, favoring tailored suits and designer sunglasses, and he has a way of making everyone feel like they're the only person in the room. He loves to regale people with stories of his supposed exploits, often embellishing the truth for dramatic effect. He's known for his confidence bordering on arrogance, and his tendency to name-drop famous people he claims to know. People might describe him as ambitious, charismatic, and maybe a little bit shady.
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and a charming smile. He comes across as confident and ambitious, always eager to share his latest "big idea" or tell a captivating story. He has a knack for making people feel like they're the only person in the room, which makes him incredibly likable. Derek often talks about his "entrepreneurial ventures," though the specifics are always vague. He loves to drop hints about his "connections" and "insider knowledge," leaving people wondering what exactly he's involved in. He might mention a "once-in-a-lifetime opportunity" he's pursuing, but he's careful not to reveal too much. Overall, casual acquaintances would probably describe Derek as a charismatic and somewhat mysterious individual, someone who seems to have a lot going on but keeps his cards close to his chest.
[08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."
[09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.

[09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Derek Wolfe casually asked Ryan, "Ryan, explain your strategy for the 'Blindfolded Taste Test' minigame," and Ryan, eager to appear clever, revealed that his plan involved memorizing the order of the dishes served in previous rounds.
